front.div:
Moog called its Ethervox the "world's first MIDI theremin". It is a fairly impressive instrument;
handcrafted mahogany cabinet, state-of-the-art circuitry, and that classic Moog theremin sound
together with MIDI control. Ethervox MIDI information is playable through the Ethervox itself or any
MIDI sound generator that can handle wide-range pitch bending.
Features of the Moog Ethervox include three pitch ranges. Tenor (two octaves above middle C,) Alto (3
octaves), and Soprano (4 octaves). The Ethervox can produce any pitch from subaudio frequencies to
the highest note of the selected range. The Etherwave's MIDI circuitry generates continuous pitch and
volume information, with pitch data transmitted as a stream pitch bend messages. The unit has
waveform, brightness, and filter controls and digital memory for storing customized presets.
Sadly, the Ethervox didn't have much time in the spotlight, and according to some reports there are
fewer than fifty Moog Ethervox owners. The Moog Ethervox is discontinued, but Moog continues to
offer support for the instrument at MoogMusic.com. You can find diagrams, a manual, and tech specs.
